newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Akihito visits Japanese colony in southern Brazil.
newsitem.headline: Akihito visits Japanese colony in southern Brazil.

text.p: Japan's Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko on Saturday greeted fans and visited a lettuce farm owned by Japanese immigrants in the southern state of Parana, the next-to-last leg of their 10-day tour of Brazil.
"The entire community is excited about their visit, even the Brazilians," said a spokeswoman for Cassio Taniguchi, the mayor of Parana's capital of Curitiba.

The imperial couple arrived on Friday night in Parana, home to the second largest colony of Japanese-Brazilians, after two days in Sao Paulo, where most of Brazil's 1.3 million citizens of Japanese descent live.

Brazilians of Japanese descent in mostly rural Parana state flocked to Curitiba, chartering 120 buses. Many awakened before dawn and travelled hours for a glimpse of the imperial couple, news reports said.
Television footage showed one man stepping off a bus waving a large Brazilian flag and shouting: "Banzai! Banzai!"
Asked what the imperial couple represented to her, elderly Mochiko Kato responded: "More than father or mother."

After meeting with 500 children and elderly on Friday, Akihito and Michiko visited on Saturday the lettuce farm and bonsai garden of 86-year-old Hiroshi Atsumi, who moved to Brazil with his wife and four children in 1959.
"The imperial couple wanted to visit a typical immigrant family, see how they lived," said the spokeswoman.
"When the family was told they would receive a visit from the emperor, they called their relatives in Japan to tell them. At first, no one believed them," she added.

The imperial couple later had lunch at Curitiba's Botanical Gardens with state Gov. Jaime Lerner and Taniguchi, the son of Japanese immigrants and the first Brazilian Japanese elected mayor of a Brazilian state capital.
"The mayor exchanged gifts with them and they spoke in Japanese," the spokeswoman said.
Later on Saturday, the imperial couple was to meet some 12,000 members of Parana state's Japanese-Brazilian community.
On Sunday, Akihito and Michiko were slated to visit a new city library before flying to Rio de Janeiro for the last leg of their Brazil tour.
Making the first Japanese imperial visit to Latin America, Akihito and Michiko will fly on Monday to Buenos Aires for a three-day visit to Argentina.
